block.p: ON THE STREET

ON THE STREET
ROCKAWAY BOARDWALK ARTS AND CRAFTS FAIR, Boardwalk at 116th Street, Queens. Tomorrow through Tuesday, 11 a.m. to dusk. Sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation.
WOODSIDE AVENUE FESTIVAL, from Roosevelt Avenue to 65th Place, Queens. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Woodside on the Move.
GREENWICH AVENUE CHAMBER FESTIVAL, from Avenue of the Americas to Eighth Avenue. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Greenwich Avenue Chamber of Commerce.

12TH 52 ASSOCIATION JAZZ FESTIVAL, 52d Street, from Lexington to Seventh Avenues. Live entertainment, crafts, food and antiques. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the 52 Association for the Handicapped Inc.
BROOKLYN AVENUE L FESTIVAL, between Rockaway Parkway and Remsen Avenue, Canarsie. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Guy M. Stewart Cancer Fund.
EVENTS
New York City

''STRIPES AND STARS: A VISUAL HISTORY OF AN AMERICAN ICON,'' American Institute of Graphic Arts, 164 Fifth Avenue, at 21st Street. An exhibition of items that incorporate the design of the flag, from buttons to cowboy boots. Through Aug. 25. Hours: Monday through Friday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; closed July 4. Free admission. Information: (212) 627-1455.

29TH INTERNATIONAL AFRICAN ARTS FESTIVAL, Boys and Girls High School Field, 1700 Fulton Street, at Utica Avenue, Bushwick, Brooklyn. An outdoor celebration with music, dance, comedy, food and a fashion show. Today through Tuesday, 10 a.m. to midnight. Admission: $7; $2 for children under 12 and the elderly; free for all on Monday before 4 p.m. Information: (718) 638-6700.

''HIGHLIGHTS OF HEROES OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION,'' Lower Manhattan. A walking tour that covers the history of the city as an English colony and during the Revolutionary War, with visits to sites of importance in the lives of Washington, Jefferson, Alexander Hamilton and others. Today at 6 p.m.; tomorrow at 10 a.m., noon and 2 p.m.; Sunday at 1 and 3 p.m.; Monday at 10 a.m., noon and 2, 4 and 6 p.m.; July 4 at 9 and 11 a.m. and 1, 3 and 5 p.m. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 629-1886.

REVOLUTIONARY WAR SITES, Lower Manhattan. A walking tour of sites like ''the Common,'' where the Declaration of Independence was first read aloud to New Yorkers, the original location of headquarters for both American and British generals and the statue of Nathan Hale. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. on the northwest corner of Warren Street and Broadway. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Fee, $5. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''GEORGE WASHINGTON, GENERAL AND PRESIDENT,'' Lower Manhattan. A walking tour past sites where Washington was inaugurated, lived, worshiped and bade farewell to his officers. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the intersection of Rector Street and Broadway. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Fee: $5. Information: (212) 265-2663.

RADICAL NEW YORK HISTORY AND ARCHITECTURE, Greenwich Village. A walking tour of sites prominent in radical history, including Emma Goldman's house and headquarters of the Catholic Workers and Cooper Union. Meets Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Peace Building, 339 Lafayette Street. Contributions accepted. Information: (718) 264-3021.

''REVOLUTIONARY MANHATTAN: A CITY OF 26,000,'' Lower Manhattan. A discussion about the area as it appeared in 1776. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. on the northwest corner of State and Whitehall Streets. Fee, $15. Sponsored by Century Walking Tours. Information: (201) 433-0946.

''ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S NEW YORK'' AND ''GEORGE WASHINGTON'S NEW YORK,'' Lower Manhattan. Two walking tours. The first, covering sites visited by Lincoln in the mid-1800's, meets tomorrow at 2 and 6 p.m. inside Blimpie's Restaurant, 36 Park Row, across from City Hall Park. The second, covers sites in Lower Manhattan known to the first president, meets Sunday at 2 and 6 p.m. inside Blimpie's Restaurant. Fee for each, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''THE TORY STORY IN LOWER MANHATTAN.'' A walking tour of pre-Revolutionary New York City through the eyes of British subjects. Led by Joyce Gold. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. in front of Trinity Church, Wall Street and Broadway. Fee: $12. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''A CELEBRATION OF AMERICAN MUSIC,'' St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 51st Street. Bernstein's ''Chichester Psalms,'' Piccolo's Canterbury Mass and Rorem's ''O Deus, Ego Amo Te,'' performed by the church choir, the Boy and Girl Choristers and the church's chamber orchestra; William Trafka, conductor; Stephen Tharp and Vincent Edwards, organists. Sunday at 11 a.m. Donations accepted. Information: (212) 378-0227.

''REVOLUTIONARY MANHATTAN: THE LEGEND OF MARGARET CORBIN,'' Fort Washington. A tour that looks at the area's involvement in the Revolution with a discussion of Corbin, who took up arms with the colonists and was wounded in a battle in 1776. Meets Sunday at 11 a.m. at the south token booth of the 207th Street subway stop of the A train. Fee: $15. Sponsored by Century Walking Tours. Information: (201) 433-0946.

INDEPENDENCE DAY CELEBRATION, Historic Richmondtown, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, Staten Island. With games, food and a civil war encampment. Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission, $4; $2.50 for children 6 to 16 years old and the elderly; free for children under 6 and members. Information: (718) 351-1611.

''GEORGE WASHINGTON'S FLUSHING,'' Queens. Traces his visits in the late 1700's on shopping trips for his home in Mount Vernon. Meets Monday at 10 a.m. outside the Flushing branch of the Queensborough Public Library, Kissena Boulevard and Main Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''WASHINGTON AND ABRAHAM LINCOLN IN BROOKLYN,'' sites of importance to the presidents in Manhattan and Brooklyn, with a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge. Meets Monday at 2 p.m. inside Blimpie's Restaurant, 36 Park Row, across from City Hall Park. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

LADY WINDRIDGE FIREWORKS CRUISE, Chelsea Pier 59, West 23rd Street and the Hudson River. A four-hour cruise with meal, music and dancing. Boards July 4 at 6:30 p.m.; sails from 7 to 11 p.m. Tickets: $375. Reservations: (212) 932-3333.

TOMMY'S AMERICAN RUNNING SERIES, Central Park. A four-mile run and races for children. July 4 at 9 a.m. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee: $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior members. Same-day registration: $22; $15 for members; $12 for junior and senior club members; kids' race fee, $6; $4 for members. Information: (212) 860-4455.

''AN AMERICAN CATHEDRAL: AN INDEPENDENCE DAY TOUR,'' Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and West 112th Street, Morningside Heights. A free tour of church spaces with American connotations, including the Poets Corner with stained glass windows depicting Betsy Ross and Francis Scott Key. July 4 at 11 a.m. Information: (212) 932-7347.

REVOLUTIONARY NEW YORK, Lower Manhattan. A walking tour of sites associated with George Washington, including Fraunces Tavern, Federal Hall and places where Washington really did sleep. Meets July 4 at 1 P.M. at Broadway and Murray Street. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''JEWISH PATRIOTS AND TORIES OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION,'' Lower Manhattan. A walking tour that celebrates the contribution Jews to the building of the country. Meets July 4 at 11 A.M. inside Blimpie's Restaurant, 38 Park Row, between Spruce and Beekman Streets. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888)377-4455.

PRE-FIREWORKS CIVIL WAR TOUR AND OPERATION SAIL VIEWING, Lower Manhattan. A tour of Civil War sites, including a Confederate prison camp and a stop on the Underground Railroad, with a viewing of the tall ships parade on July 4. Tomorrow at 2 and 5 p.m. Also Sunday, Monday and July 4, same times. Fee: $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Information: (212) 465-3331.
Hudson Valley

ALL-AMERICAN PICNIC, Boscobel Restoration, 1601 Route 9D, Garrison. With a reading of the Declaration of Independence, entertainment and food. Sunday, 11:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Admission: $20; $8 for children 4 to 13. Picnic with performance of ''Measure for Measure,'' by the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, at 6 p.m. Admission: $45; children 13 and younger, $22. Reservations: (845) 265-3638. The play runs through July 30. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m; Sunday at 6 p.m. Show tickets only: $17 to $30. Information: (845) 265-7858.

FEEL THE BEAT, Lasdon Park and Arboretum, Route 35, Somers. Featuring Ti Ayiti, a Haitian drum and dance troupe. Tomorrow at 6 p.m.; gates open for picnicking at 5. Tickets: $10; $3 for children 18 and younger. Information: (914) 693-5595.

PLAYLAND PARK, Exit 19 of Interstate 95, Rye. Tonight and tomorrow, noon to midnight. Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursday, noon to 11 p.m. Also Monday from noon to midnight. Admission: free. Rides require 3 to 6 tickets each; 12-ticket book, $8; 24-ticket book, $15; 36-ticket book, $19. Parking: weekdays, $4; weekends, $5; holidays, $7. Fireworks displays Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at 9:15 p.m. (914) 925-2700.
GREAT AMERICAN WEEKEND, Goshen. Featuring car shows, entertainment, walking tours, food and exhibits. Tomorrow, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (877) 496-4869.

SALUTE TO AMERICA CONCERT, Shaker Museum and Library, 88 Shaker Museum road, Old Chatham. A performance by the Columbia Festival Orchestra featuring Copland's ''Lincoln Portrait,'' with narration by Al Roker. Tomorrow at 6 p.m. Tickets, $20, $15 advance; free for children under 18. Information: (518) 392-7198.

KENSICO DAM MUSIC FESTIVAL, north end of Bronx River Parkway, Valhalla. Monday. Gates open at 5 p.m. for picnicking. Concert begins at 7, featuring Dixieland and samba music. Free. Information: (914) 242-7275.

INDEPENDENCE DAY CELEBRATION, St. Paul's Church National Historic Site, 897 South Columbus Avenue, Mount Vernon. With music, speeches, a reading of the Declaration of Independence and refreshments. Tuesday beginning at 10 a.m. Costumed demonstration of ''Pell's Point: The Battle that Saved Washington's Army'' Wednesday at 12:15 p.m. Both free. Information: (914) 667-4116.

CELEBRATE INDEPENDENCE DAY OF 1855, Sunnyside, West Sunnyside Lane (off Route 9), Tarrytown. With games, a pie-judging contest, town ball game, children's lawn games, music and dancing. Tuesday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $7 for the elderly; $4 for children 5 to 17; free for children under 5. Picnicking allowed. Information: (914) 591-8763.
MUSIC UNDER THE STARS, Trophy Point Amphitheater, West Point. A performance by the United States Military Academy Band of Glenn Miller music. Sunday at 7:30 p.m. Free. Information: (845) 938-2617.
New Jersey

PNC BANK ARTS CENTER, Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. Jimmy Page and the Black Crowes. Today at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $33 to $87. The Who. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $87. Britney Spears. Sunday and July 3 at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $44.50. Information: (201) 507-8900.

''STAR-SPANGLED BRASS,'' Stockton Performing Arts Center, Jim Leeds Road, Pomona (Exit 44, Garden State Parkway). Featuring the River City Brass Band. Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $18 and $24. Information: (609) 652-4527.
''CARMEN,'' McCarter Theater, 91 University Place, Princeton. Presented by the Opera Festival of New Jersey. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $24 to $82. Information: (609) 258-2787.

NEW JERSEY SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL, F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison. ''The Forest,'' a comedy by Alexander Ostrovsky. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $24 to $38. Information: (973) 408-5600.

PLAYS IN THE PARK ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' The musical. Tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $3; free for children under 13. Stephen J. Capestro Theater, Roosevelt Park, off Route 1 South, Edison. Information: (732) 548-2884.

''THEATER OF LIGHT: JERSEY CITY,'' a light show featuring painted images by Rudi Stern, to be projected onto the facade of the Hartz Mountain Industries building, 90 Hudson Street. Monday through July 9, sundown to 1 a.m. Visible in lower Manhattan along the Hudson River from Battery Park City to 23rd Street. Sponsored by the Jersey City Economic Development Corporation.

''AN ALL-AMERICAN CELEBRATION WITH THE NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA'' Two concerts in the free Chase Manhattan Bank Summer Pops Tour. Tonight at 7:30 at Brookdale Park in Bloomfield/ Montclair, entrance on Watchung Avenue in Bloomfield; tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. at Mercer County Park, Route 535 (Old Trenton Road), West Windsor. Information: (973) 624-3713.

MEADOWLANDS FAIR Giants Stadium, Meadowlands Sports Complex, Route 3, East Rutherford. Rides, food and games. Through July 9. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 6 p.m. to 1 a.m.; Fridays, 6 p.m. to 2 a.m.; Saturdays, noon to 2 a.m.; Sundays, noon to midnight. Tickets: $6 (Mondays through Fridays); $8 (Saturdays and Sundays); $3 for children under 12 (Mondays through Fridays); $4 (Saturdays and Sundays); free for children under 34 inches tall. Parking: $2. Information: (201) 933-0199.
Connecticut
MUSIC AND FIREWORKS, Meadowbrook Golf Course, 2761 Dixwell Avenue, Hamden. Featuring the Hamden Wind Symphony. Tonight at 7; rain date, tomorrow. Free.
ROY BOOKBINDER, Buttonwood Tree, 605 Main Street, Middletown. Blues guitarist. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Donation: $10. Information: (860) 347-4957.

77th ROUND HILL HIGHLAND SCOTTISH GAMES, Cranbury Park, Grumman Avenue, Norwalk. With music, competitions and food. Tomorrow, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission, $10; $5 for children and the elderly. Information: (203) 324-1094.

INDEPENDENCE DAY POPS CONCERT OF AMERICAN MUSIC, Harkness Memorial State Park, off Route 1 north, Waterford. Featuring the Connecticut Orchestra, with fireworks. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets, $28 to $33; lawn seats, $16.50, $15 in advance; children under 12, half-price; free under age 5. Picnicking allowed. Information: (860) 444-7373.

FOURTH OF JULY FIREWORKS CONCERT, Ives Concert Park, Western Connecticut State University, Westside campus, Danbury. Ridgefield Symphony Orchestra, with Frank Tenaglia, tenor. Tuesday at 7 p.m. Reserved seats, $35; lawn seats, $25; children ages 3 to 12, $10. Information: (203) 837-9226.
NEW HAVEN INDEPENDENCE DAY CONCERT WITH FIREWORKS, Long Wharf Park, Long Wharf Drive, Exit 46 off Interstate 95, New Haven. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. Information: (203) 946-7821.

25TH SHELBY AMERICAN AUTOMOBILE CLUB NATIONAL CONVENTION, Lime Rock Park, 497 Lime Rock Road, Lakeville. One thousand championship cars produced by Carroll Shelby from 1961 to 1970, exhibited on Sunday, and auto racing on Monday. Hours: Sunday, 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Monday, 8:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $15 a day. Information: (800) 722-3577.

BASEBALL, New Britain Stadium, New Britain. Class AA : New Britain Rockcats vs. Norwich Navigators. Sunday at 2 p.m. and Monday at 7 p.m. Admission: $3.75; children, $1.25. Information: (860) 224-8383.
Long Island
BETTY BUCKLEY, Guild Hall, John Drew Theater, Main Street, East Hampton. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $65. Information: (631) 324-4050.
PORT JEFFERSON FESTIVAL, Terryville Road. Today through Monday, 6 p.m to midnight. Sponsored by the Port Jefferson Lions Club. Information: (631) 331-2832.
GARDEN TOUR, Shelter Island. Tomorrow, 2 to 5 p.m. Benefit for the Shelter Island Education Foundation. Admission: $25 for all five gardens. Information: (631) 749-2352.
''FIRECRACKER 8K RUN,'' Agawam Park, Southampton. Sunday at 9 a.m. Sponsored by the Southhampton Rotary Club. Admission: $20. Information: (631) 726-4580.
4K RUN, Riverside Boardwalk, Long Beach. July 4 at 8:45 a.m., preceded at 8:30 by a 1k run for children. Fee: $20. Information: (516) 431-3890.
5K RUN, Miller Avenue School, Shoreham. Tuesday at 8:30 a.m. Fee: $14. Information: (631) 821-8116.
